title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement koen.niemeijer@kuleuven.. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to mpathwear
text: outlines propose change mpathwear. detailed discussion contributing package, please see tidyverse’s development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to mpathwear
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to mpathwear
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See tidyverse’s guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to mpathwear
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("m-path-io/mpathwear", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to mpathwear
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to mpathwear
text: Please note mpathwear project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Get started
text: vignette shows minimal workflow using mpathwear package. vignette, use example data included package. example dataset downloaded directly m-Path (see manual download data) thus similar dataset real study. First, set path variable points data, case within mpathwear: Next, can use read_mpathwear() function read data R. Note downloaded data iteratively m-Path (e.g. every day backups), data overlap data export m-Path cumulative. Nevertheless, read_mpathwear() automatically remove duplicate rows fail day yet completed.
code: # Path to the example data shipped with the package path <- system.file("extdata", "example.csv", package = "mpathwear") # Read the data (this can also be a directory containing multiple exported CSVs) raw <- read_mpathwear(path)  head(raw) #> # A tibble: 3 × 9 #>   connectionId legacyCode  code     alias initials accountCode lastCreatedAtUnix #>   <chr>        <chr>       <chr>    <chr> <chr>    <chr>                   <dbl> #> 1 123456       !1234@abc12 !abcd e… exam… exa      abc12           1764164955448 #> 2 123456       !1234@abc12 !abcd e… exam… exa      abc12           1764165350362 #> 3 123456       !1234@abc12 !abcd e… exam… exa      abc12           1764166043493 #> # ℹ 2 more variables: dynamicData <list>, dailyData <list>

title: Get started
text: read_mpathwear() returns raw exported rows containing JSON-encoded daily dynamic measurements. functions clean_daily_data() clean_dynamic_data() unpack JSON blobs return tidy tibbles suitable plotting analysis. larger datasets, clean_dynamic_data() may take time finish running (e.g. several) minutes.
code: # Clean interday (daily) summary data # Drop the dynamicData column since this cannot be combined with daily data anyway daily <- raw |>    select(-"dynamicData") |>   clean_daily_data()  glimpse(daily) #> Rows: 387 #> Columns: 18 #> $ connectionId      <chr> "123456", "123456", "123456", "123456", "123456", "1… #> $ legacyCode        <chr> "!1234@abc12", "!1234@abc12", "!1234@abc12", "!1234@… #> $ code              <chr> "!abcd efgh", "!abcd efgh", "!abcd efgh", "!abcd efg… #> $ alias             <chr> "example_user", "example_user", "example_user", "exa… #> $ initials          <chr> "exa", "exa", "exa", "exa", "exa", "exa", "exa", "ex… #> $ accountCode       <chr> "abc12", "abc12", "abc12", "abc12", "abc12", "abc12"… #> $ lastCreatedAtUnix <dbl> 1.764165e+12, 1.764165e+12, 1.764165e+12, 1.764165e+… #> $ day               <date> 2025-11-12, 2025-11-12, 2025-11-12, 2025-11-12, 202… #> $ category          <chr> "Activity", "Activity", "Activity", "Activity", "Act… #> $ subcategory       <chr> "Steps", "CoveredDistance", "FloorsClimbed", "Elevat… #> $ variable          <chr> "Steps", "CoveredDistance", "FloorsClimbed", "Elevat… #> $ value             <chr> "4402", "3661.0", "5", "15.0", "2370", "195", "14", … #> $ timezoneOffset    <int> 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, … #> $ generation        <chr> NA, NA, NA, "calculation", NA, NA, "calculation", NA… #> $ created_at        <dttm> 2025-11-26 13:48:37, 2025-11-26 13:48:37, 2025-11-2… #> $ data_source       <chr> "Garmin", "Garmin", "Garmin", "Garmin", "Garmin", "G… #> $ description       <chr> "sum of steps (including the manually added values)"… #> $ available_sources <list> <"Apple", "Beurer", "Decathlon", "Fitbit", "Garmin"… # Clean intraday (dynamic) data # Drop the dailyData column since this cannot be combined with dynamic data anyway dynamic <- raw |>    select(-"dailyData") |>    clean_dynamic_data()  glimpse(dynamic) #> Rows: 37,332 #> Columns: 19 #> $ connectionId      <chr> "123456", "123456", "123456", "123456", "123456", "1… #> $ legacyCode        <chr> "!1234@abc12", "!1234@abc12", "!1234@abc12", "!1234@… #> $ code              <chr> "!abcd efgh", "!abcd efgh", "!abcd efgh", "!abcd efg… #> $ alias             <chr> "example_user", "example_user", "example_user", "exa… #> $ initials          <chr> "exa", "exa", "exa", "exa", "exa", "exa", "exa", "ex… #> $ accountCode       <chr> "abc12", "abc12", "abc12", "abc12", "abc12", "abc12"… #> $ lastCreatedAtUnix <dbl> 1.764165e+12, 1.764165e+12, 1.764165e+12, 1.764165e+… #> $ start_time        <dttm> 2025-11-23 11:36:00, 2025-11-12 09:11:15, 2025-11-2… #> $ end_time          <dttm> 2025-11-23 11:39:00, 2025-11-12 09:12:15, 2025-11-2… #> $ category          <chr> "Stress", "Cardiovascular", "Sleep", "Activity", "Ca… #> $ subcategory       <chr> "Stress", "HeartRate", "SleepInBedDuration", "Steps"… #> $ variable          <chr> "Stress", "HeartRate", "SleepInBedBinary", "Steps", … #> $ value             <chr> "27", "82", "true", "14.0", "68", "54", "25", "true"… #> $ tz_offset         <int> 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, … #> $ generation        <chr> NA, NA, "automated_measurement", "automated_measurem… #> $ created_at        <dttm> 2025-11-26 13:48:37, 2025-11-26 13:48:37, 2025-11-2… #> $ data_source       <chr> "Garmin", "Garmin", "Garmin", "Garmin", "Garmin", "G… #> $ description       <chr> "stress measured during that period scaling from 0 t… #> $ available_sources <list> "Garmin", <"Apple", "Beurer", "Fitbit", "Garmin", "…

title: Get started
text: example charts demonstrate common visualizations wearable data. overview charting functions, see reference section.

title: Get started
text: First , may want know extent data actually gathered. can inspect using coverage chart plots whether data present absent time. daily data, can use daily_coverage_chart() plots participant ID y-axis day number (0 day 1, 1 day 2 etc.) x-axis variables displayed facets. gives good indication complete data . Note necessarily variables present days. First , devices may support variables means always absent. Second, variables continuous rather event-driven. instance, high activity event certain day, ActivityHighDuration absent. way, implicit 0 may want take account running analyses.  can thing intraday data using coverage_chart(), bars per day rather displayed actual duration. , daily coverage chart shows whether data present day, intradaily coverage chart shows exactly often data collected across time spans. Like daily coverage chart, “missing” data need truly missing. instance, RunBinary occur participant run recorded period. hand, one hope HeartRate somewhat continuously present. conclusion, chart shows often data present variable time.

title: Get started
text: daily_chart() function visualizes daily summary variables time single participant. variable plotted facet.

title: Get started
text: Show activity types across days using activity_chart().

title: Get started
text: heart_rate_chart() shows heart rate time well average heart rate day.
code: heart_rate_chart(dynamic) #> Warning: Removed 1 row containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_segment()`).

title: Get started
text: package includes helpers sleep visualisation commonly used sleep metrics. sleep_chart() function visualises sleep stages (awake, REM, light, deep) across nights. helpers compute durations scores intraday (dynamic) data.  show sleep metric helpers. returns tibble day corresponding metric (seconds intraday-derived metrics). merge , can use Reduce() call function add result using full_join().

title: Authors and Citation
text: Koen Niemeijer. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Niemeijer K (2025). mpathwear: Imports visualises wearable data 'm-Path'. R package version 0.1.0, https://github.com/koenniem/mpathwear.
code: @Manual{,   title = {mpathwear: Imports and visualises wearable data from 'm-Path'},   author = {Koen Niemeijer},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://github.com/koenniem/mpathwear}, }

what: Imports and visualises wearable data from m-Path
title: Imports and visualises wearable data from m-Path
text: NOTE: package highly experimental still early development. goal mpathwear help users import wearable data gathered m-Path. Importantly, helps unpack exported CSV file m-Path neatly sorts intraday daily data measurement IDs converted human readable format.

title: Imports and visualises wearable data from m-Path
text: can install development version mpathwear Github:

title: Imports and visualises wearable data from m-Path
text: overview functions package, see mpathwear Reference Site. m-Path related data, see mpathr regular m-Path questionnaire data, mpathsenser m-Path sensor data.

title: Imports and visualises wearable data from m-Path
text: encounter clear bug need help getting function run, please file issue minimal reproducible example Github.

title: Imports and visualises wearable data from m-Path
text: Please note mpathwear project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

what: Create an activity type chart — activity_chart
title: Create an activity type chart — activity_chart
text: Creates visualization activity types time wearable data. chart can display activities either merged horizontal bars per day individual activity segments transitions.

title: Create an activity type chart — activity_chart
code: activity_chart(   .data,   start = "start_time",   end = "end_time",   variable = "variable",   value = "value",   tz_offset = "tz_offset",   merged_bars = TRUE )

title: Create an activity type chart — activity_chart
text: .data data frame containing wearable data. start name column containing start timestamps. Defaults "start_time". end name column containing end timestamps. Defaults "end_time". variable name column containing variable names. Defaults "variable". value name column containing measurement values. Defaults "value". tz_offset name column containing timezone offsets. Defaults "tz_offset". merged_bars Logical. TRUE (default), activities shown single row per day. FALSE, activities shown vertical transitions states.

title: Create an activity type chart — activity_chart
text: ggplot2::ggplot object displaying activity types time.

title: Create an activity type chart — activity_chart
code: # Show a single timeline activity_chart(dynamic_data)   # Display activities with transitions activity_chart(dynamic_data, merged_bars = FALSE)

Defaults "value". tz_offset name column containing timezone offsets. Defaults "tz_offset".

text: ggplot2::ggplot object displaying activity intensity levels time.

what: Overview of Thryve measurement codes and descriptions — codebook
title: Overview of Thryve measurement codes and descriptions — codebook
text: table containing connection Thryve ID codes measurements listed dailyValueType dynamicValueType columns mpathwear data, along descriptions, units, available data sources.

title: Overview of Thryve measurement codes and descriptions — codebook
Overview of Thryve measurement codes and descriptions — codebook
text: data frame 344 rows 8 columns: category overall category measurement. subcategory specific category measurement. level measurement variable, .e. Daily Intraday variable variable name measurement. description description measurement. code Thryve code measurement, used dailyDynamicValueType dynamicValueType columns mpathwear data. unit unit measurement, used valueType column mpathwear data. available_sources available data sources (e.g. Garmin, Fitbit) type measurement.

title: Overview of Thryve measurement codes and descriptions — codebook

what: Create a continuous value chart — continuous_chart
title: Create a continuous value chart — continuous_chart
text: Internal function creates faceted line chart continuous wearable data measurements time.

title: Create a continuous value chart — continuous_chart
code: continuous_chart(.data, type, start, end, variable, value, tz_offset)

title: Create a continuous value chart — continuous_chart
text: .data data frame containing wearable data. type character vector variable types filter (e.g., "HeartRate", "Stress"). start name column containing start timestamps. Defaults "start_time". end name column containing end timestamps. Defaults "end_time". variable name column containing variable names. Defaults "variable". value name column containing measurement values. Defaults "value". tz_offset name column containing timezone offsets. Defaults "tz_offset".

title: Create a continuous value chart — continuous_chart
text: ggplot2::ggplot object displaying continuous data line chart faceted date.

title: Create a data coverage chart — coverage_chart
text: .data data frame containing wearable data, typically clean_dynamic_data(). participant name column containing participant identifiers. Defaults "connectionId". start name column containing start timestamps. Defaults "start_time". end name column containing end timestamps. Defaults "end_time". variable name column containing variable names. Defaults "variable". tz_offset name column containing timezone offsets. Defaults "tz_offset".

title: Create a data coverage chart — coverage_chart
text: ggplot2::ggplot object displaying data coverage horizontal segments per participant, faceted variable type.

title: Create a data coverage chart — coverage_chart

what: Example dataset of daily measurements — daily_data
title: Example dataset of daily measurements — daily_data
text: dataset containing example 7 days daily measurements single participant. Exported m-Path cleaned using clean_daily_data() demonstration purposes.

title: Example dataset of daily measurements — daily_data

what: daily_data A data frame with 387 rows and 18 columns:
title: Example dataset of daily measurements — daily_data
text: connectionId participant ID m-Path. legacyCode legacy invitation code format. Corresponds directly code. code invitation code used study, . alias alias participant (can changed participant point). initials initials participant based first seen alias. accountCode account code researcher. lastCreatedAtUnix last Unix timestamp wearable data updated. day day measurement. category overall category measurement. subcategory specific category measurement. variable variable name measurement. value value measurement. timezoneOffset timezone offset measurement compared UTC. generation Whether measurement  calculation, automatic measurement, manual input. created_at time measurement created updated. data_source data source measurement. Also see data_sources. description description measurement. available_sources available data sources (e.g. Garmin, Fitbit) type measurement.

what: Overview of supported Thryve data sources and data retrieval periods — data_sources
title: Overview of supported Thryve data sources and data retrieval periods — data_sources
text: table containing connection Thryve ID codes activity types listed value column variables ActivityTypeDetail1 ActivityTypeDetail2.

title: Overview of supported Thryve data sources and data retrieval periods — data_sources
Overview of supported Thryve data sources and data retrieval periods — data_sources
text: data frame 38 rows 5 columns: id ID number data source Thryve. data_source name data source. type_integration Thryve connects data source, e.g. oAuth (via API). data_retrieval_frequency often data pulled data source. type_data_source status integration data sources Thryve. One "active", "experimental", "thryve".

title: Overview of supported Thryve data sources and data retrieval periods — data_sources
text: https://docs-old.thryve.health/access.php#data-sources

what: Create a discrete state chart — discrete_chart
title: Create a discrete state chart — discrete_chart
text: Internal function creates faceted segment chart discrete wearable data states time (e.g., sleep stages, activity intensity levels).

title: Create a discrete state chart — discrete_chart
code: discrete_chart(   .data,   types,   names,   start,   end,   variable,   value,   tz_offset,   .call = rlang::caller_env() )

title: Create a discrete state chart — discrete_chart
text: .data data frame containing wearable data. types character vector variable types filter . names character vector display names corresponding types. start name column containing start timestamps. Defaults "start_time". end name column containing end timestamps. Defaults "end_time". variable name column containing variable names. Defaults "variable". value name column containing measurement values. Defaults "value". tz_offset name column containing timezone offsets. Defaults "tz_offset". .call calling environment error messages.

title: Create a discrete state chart — discrete_chart
text: ggplot2::ggplot object displaying discrete states horizontal segments faceted day.

what: Example dataset of intradaily (i.e. dynamic) measurements — dynamic_data
title: Example dataset of intradaily (i.e. dynamic) measurements — dynamic_data
text: dataset containing example 7 days intradaily (.e. dynamic) measurements single participant. Exported m-Path cleaned using clean_dynamic_data() demonstration purposes.

title: Example dataset of intradaily (i.e. dynamic) measurements — dynamic_data

what: dynamic_data A data frame with 37,332 rows and 19 columns:
title: Example dataset of intradaily (i.e. dynamic) measurements — dynamic_data
text: connectionId participant ID m-Path. legacyCode legacy invitation code format. Corresponds directly code. code invitation code used study, . alias alias participant (can changed participant point). initials initials participant based first seen alias. accountCode account code researcher. lastCreatedAtUnix last Unix timestamp wearable data updated. start_time start time measurement. end_time end time measurement. category overall category measurement. subcategory specific category measurement. variable variable name measurement. value value measurement. tz_offset timezone offset measurement compared UTC. generation Whether measurement  calculation, automatic measurement, manual input. created_at time measurement created updated. data_source data source measurement. Also see data_sources. description description measurement. available_sources available data sources (e.g. Garmin, Fitbit) type measurement.

what: Create a heart rate chart — heart_rate_chart
title: Create a heart rate chart — heart_rate_chart
text: Creates visualization heart rate measurements time wearable data. chart displays heart rate values optional daily average lines.

title: Create a heart rate chart — heart_rate_chart
code: heart_rate_chart(   .data,   start = "start_time",   end = "end_time",   variable = "variable",   value = "value",   tz_offset = "tz_offset",   add_average = TRUE )

title: Create a heart rate chart — heart_rate_chart
text: .data data frame containing wearable data. start name column containing start timestamps. Defaults "start_time". end name column containing end timestamps. Defaults "end_time". variable name column containing variable names. Defaults "variable". value name column containing measurement values. Defaults "value". tz_offset name column containing timezone offsets. Defaults "tz_offset". add_average Logical. TRUE (default), adds dashed horizontal line showing daily average heart rate.

title: Create a heart rate chart — heart_rate_chart
text: ggplot2::ggplot object displaying heart rate measurements faceted date.

title: Create a heart rate chart — heart_rate_chart
code: heart_rate_chart(dynamic_data) #> Warning: Removed 1 row containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_segment()`).

text: .data data frame containing wearable data. start name column containing start timestamps. Defaults "start_time". end name column containing end timestamps. Defaults "end_time". variable name column containing variable names. Defaults "variable". value name column containing measurement values. Defaults "value". tz_offset name column containing timezone offsets. Defaults "tz_offset". add_average Logical. TRUE (default), adds dashed horizontal line showing daily average HRV.

text: ggplot2::ggplot object displaying HRV measurements faceted date.

title: Create a heart rate variability (HRV) chart — hrv_chart

what: Read wearable data from m-Path — read_mpathwear
title: Read wearable data from m-Path — read_mpathwear
text: function reads one multiple CSV files containing wearable data exported m-Path.

title: Read wearable data from m-Path — read_mpathwear
Read wearable data from m-Path — read_mpathwear
text: path character string directory containing data files single file path. recursive logical value indicating whether data files searched subdirectories.

title: Read wearable data from m-Path — read_mpathwear
text: tibble containing following columns: See m-Path manual page data exporting information columns connectionId accountCode, part default m-Path data output.

title: Read wearable data from m-Path — read_mpathwear
code: # Your path to the data, or in this case the package example data. # Note that this can also be a folder containing several files. path <- system.file("extdata", "example.csv", package = "mpathwear")  read_mpathwear(path) #> # A tibble: 3 × 9 #>   connectionId legacyCode  code     alias initials accountCode lastCreatedAtUnix #>   <chr>        <chr>       <chr>    <chr> <chr>    <chr>                   <dbl> #> 1 123456       !1234@abc12 !abcd e… exam… exa      abc12           1764164955448 #> 2 123456       !1234@abc12 !abcd e… exam… exa      abc12           1764165350362 #> 3 123456       !1234@abc12 !abcd e… exam… exa      abc12           1764166043493 #> # ℹ 2 more variables: dynamicData <list>, dailyData <list>

title: Calculate sleep onset latency — sleep_onset_latency
text: data frame columns day SleepOnSetLatency (seconds).

title: Calculate sleep onset latency — sleep_onset_latency
code: # Calculate the sleep onset latency from # intraday (dynamic) data. sleep_onset_latency(dynamic_data) #> # A tibble: 15 × 3 #>    connectionId day        SleepOnSetLatency #>    <chr>        <date>                 <int> #>  1 123456       2025-11-12                 0 #>  2 123456       2025-11-13                 0 #>  3 123456       2025-11-14                 0 #>  4 123456       2025-11-15                 0 #>  5 123456       2025-11-16                 0 #>  6 123456       2025-11-17                 0 #>  7 123456       2025-11-18                 0 #>  8 123456       2025-11-19                 0 #>  9 123456       2025-11-20                 0 #> 10 123456       2025-11-21                 0 #> 11 123456       2025-11-22                 0 #> 12 123456       2025-11-23                 0 #> 13 123456       2025-11-24                 0 #> 14 123456       2025-11-25                 0 #> 15 123456       2025-11-26                 0  # We can compare this to the sleep onset latency from the # daily data. # Note that in the daily data, the sleep onset latency is shown # in minutes instead of seconds. daily_data[daily_data$variable == "SleepLatency", c("day", "value")] #> # A tibble: 0 × 2 #> # ℹ 2 variables: day <date>, value <chr>

title: Calculate sleep regularity index — sleep_regularity
text: Calculates Sleep Regularity Index (SRI), describes likelihood two time-points 24 hours apart sleep/wake state across days. well-established indicator sleep consistency.

title: Calculate sleep regularity index — sleep_regularity
Calculate sleep regularity index — sleep_regularity
text: .data data frame containing wearable data, typically clean_dynamic_data(). start name column containing start timestamps. Defaults "start_time". end name column containing end timestamps. Defaults "end_time". variable name column containing variable names. Defaults "variable". tz_offset name column containing timezone offsets. Defaults "tz_offset".

title: Calculate sleep regularity index — sleep_regularity
text: data frame sleep_regularity score (ranging -100 100, 100 indicates perfect regularity).

title: Calculate sleep regularity index — sleep_regularity
text: Values 60% associated significantly higher likelihood Alzheimer's disease, depression, cardiovascular diseases.

title: Calculate sleep regularity index — sleep_regularity
text: function requires mpathsenser package installed.

title: Calculate sleep regularity index — sleep_regularity

title: Calculate total REM sleep duration — sleep_rem_duration
text: data frame columns day SleepREMDuration (seconds).

title: Calculate total REM sleep duration — sleep_rem_duration
Calculate composite sleep score — sleep_score
text: Calculates composite sleep quality score based multiple sleep metrics including onset latency, duration, efficiency, awake time, proportions deep REM sleep.

title: Calculate composite sleep score — sleep_score
Calculate composite sleep score — sleep_score
text: .data data frame containing wearable data, typically clean_dynamic_data(). start name column containing start timestamps. Defaults "start_time". end name column containing end timestamps. Defaults "end_time". variable name column containing variable names. Defaults "variable". tz_offset name column containing timezone offsets. Defaults "tz_offset".

title: Calculate composite sleep score — sleep_score
text: data frame columns day sleep_score. Lower scores indicate better sleep quality.

title: Calculate composite sleep score — sleep_score
text: scoring based Arora et al. (2020). calculated sleep quality scores ranges 0 14, lower scores denotes better sleep quality.

title: Calculate composite sleep score — sleep_score
text: Arora, ., Chakraborty, P., & Bhatia, M. P. S. (2020). Analysis Data Wearable Sensors Sleep Quality Estimation Prediction Using Deep Learning. Arabian Journal Science Engineering, 45(12), 10793-10812. doi:10.1007/s13369-020-04877-w

title: Create a stress level chart — stress_chart
text: .data data frame containing wearable data. start name column containing start timestamps. Defaults "start_time". end name column containing end timestamps. Defaults "end_time". variable name column containing variable names. Defaults "variable". value name column containing measurement values. Defaults "value". tz_offset name column containing timezone offsets. Defaults "tz_offset". add_average Logical. TRUE (default), adds dashed horizontal line showing daily average stress level.

what: Summarise Overlapping and Contiguous Time Intervals — summarise_overlapping_time
title: Summarise Overlapping and Contiguous Time Intervals — summarise_overlapping_time
text: Summarise rows dataset start next interval (nearly) equal end current interval, indicating contiguous. useful simplifying sequences adjacent time intervals broader continuous spans. also summarises time intervals overlap.

title: Summarise Overlapping and Contiguous Time Intervals — summarise_overlapping_time
Summarise Overlapping and Contiguous Time Intervals — summarise_overlapping_time
text: .data data frame containing least start end time columns. start name column indicating start times. Defaults "start_time". end name column indicating end times. Defaults "end_time". tolerance numeric value indicating maximum difference end one interval start next interval consider contiguous. Defaults 0.

title: Summarise Overlapping and Contiguous Time Intervals — summarise_overlapping_time
text: data frame collapsed contiguous time intervals, row represents continuous span.

title: Summarise Overlapping and Contiguous Time Intervals — summarise_overlapping_time
code: df <- data.frame(   start_time = c(1, 2, 4, 5),   end_time = c(2, 3, 5, 6) ) summarise_overlapping_time(   df,   start = start_time,   end = end_time ) #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   start_time end_time #>        <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1          1        3 #> 2          4        6
